{{Day}}

==Events==
* [[752]] &ndash; Mayan king [[Yaxun B'alam IV|Bird Jaguar IV]] of [[Yaxchilan]] in modern-day [[Chiapas]], Mexico assumes the throne.
[[File:El Tres de Mayo, by Francisco de Goya, from Prado thin black margin.jpg|thumb|''[[The Third of May 1808]]'' by [[Francisco de Goya]], depicting the execution of Madrid citizens on that date by French forces during the [[Peninsular War]]]]
*[[1481]] &ndash; The [[1481 Rhodes earthquake|largest of three earthquakes]] strikes the island of [[Rhodes]] and causes an estimated 30,000 casualties.
*[[1491]] &ndash; [[Kingdom of Kongo|Kongo]] monarch [[Nkuwu Nzinga]] is baptised by [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] missionaries, adopting the baptismal name of [[João I of Kongo|João I]].
*[[1791]] &ndash; The [[Constitution of May 3, 1791|Constitution of May 3]] (the first modern [[constitution]] in Europe) is proclaimed by the [[Sejm]] of [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]].
*[[1802]] &ndash; [[Washington, D.C.]] is incorporated as a city.
*[[1808]] &ndash; [[Finnish War]]: Sweden loses the fortress of [[Sveaborg]] to Russia.
*  1808   &ndash; [[Peninsular War]]: The [[Madrid]] rebels who rose up on [[May 2]] are executed near [[Príncipe Pío]] hill.
*[[1815]] &ndash; [[Neapolitan War]]: [[Joachim Murat]], King of [[Kingdom of Naples|Naples]] is defeated by the Austrians at the [[Battle of Tolentino]], the decisive engagement of the war.
*[[1830]] &ndash; The [[Canterbury and Whitstable Railway]] is opened.  It's the first steam hauled passenger railway to issue season tickets and include a tunnel.
*[[1837]] &ndash; The [[National and Kapodistrian University of Athens|University of Athens]] is founded in [[Athens]], Greece.
*[[1849]] &ndash; The [[May Uprising in Dresden]] begins &ndash; the last of the [[The Revolutions of 1848 in the German states|German revolutions of 1848]].
*[[1855]] &ndash; American [[adventurer]] [[William Walker (filibuster)|William Walker]] departs from [[San Francisco]] with about 60 men to conquer [[Nicaragua]].
*[[1860]] &ndash; [[Charles XV of Sweden|Charles XV]] of [[Sweden–Norway]] is crowned king of Sweden.
*[[1867]] &ndash; The [[Hudson's Bay Company]] gives up all claims to [[Vancouver Island]].
*[[1877]] &ndash; [[Labatt Park]], the oldest continually operating baseball grounds in the world has its first game.
*[[1901]] &ndash; The [[Great Fire of 1901]] begins in [[Jacksonville, Florida]].
*[[1913]] &ndash; ''[[Raja Harishchandra]]'' the first full-length Indian [[feature film]] is released, marking the beginning of the [[Cinema of India|Indian film industry]].
*[[1915]] &ndash; The poem ''[[In Flanders Fields]]'' is written by Lieutenant Colonel [[John McCrae]].
*[[1920]] &ndash; A [[1920 Georgian coup attempt|Bolshevik coup]] fails in the [[Democratic Republic of Georgia]].
*[[1921]] &ndash; [[West Virginia]] becomes the first state to legislate a broad [[sales tax]], but does not implement it until a number of years later due to enforcement issues.
*[[1928]] &ndash; Japanese atrocities in [[Jinan Incident|Jinan]], China.
*[[1937]] &ndash; ''[[Gone with the Wind]]'', a novel by [[Margaret Mitchell]], wins the [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]].
*[[1939]] &ndash; The [[All India Forward Bloc]] is formed by Netaji [[Subhas Chandra Bose]].
*[[1942]] &ndash; [[World War II]]: [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] naval troops [[Invasion of Tulagi (May 1942)|invade Tulagi]] Island in the [[Solomon Islands]] during the first part of [[Operation Mo]] that results in the [[Battle of the Coral Sea]] between Japanese forces and forces from the United States and Australia.
*[[1945]] &ndash; World War II: Sinking of the [[prison ship]]s ''[[Cap Arcona]], [[Thielbek]]'' and ''[[Deutschland IV (liner)|Deutschland]]'' by the [[Royal Air Force]] in  [[Lübeck Bay]].
*[[1947]] &ndash; New post-war [[Constitution of Japan|Japanese constitution]] goes into effect.
*[[1948]] &ndash; The [[U.S. Supreme Court]] rules in [[Shelley v. Kraemer]] that covenants prohibiting the sale of [[real estate]] to blacks and other minorities are legally unenforceable.
*[[1951]] &ndash; London's [[Royal Festival Hall]] opens with the [[Festival of Britain]].
*  1951   &ndash; The [[United States Senate]] [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|Armed Services]] and [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Foreign Relations]] Committees begin their closed door hearings into the dismissal of [[General]] [[Douglas MacArthur]] by [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Harry Truman]].
*[[1952]] &ndash; [[Lieutenant Colonel]]s [[Joseph O. Fletcher]] and [[William P. Benedict]] of the United States land a plane at the [[North Pole]].
*  1952   &ndash; The [[Kentucky Derby]] is televised nationally for the first time, on the [[CBS]] network.
*[[1957]] &ndash; [[Walter O'Malley]], the owner of the [[Los Angeles Dodgers|Brooklyn Dodgers]], agrees to move the team from [[Brooklyn, New York]], to [[Los Angeles, California]].
*[[1960]] &ndash; The [[Off-Broadway]] [[musical comedy]], ''[[The Fantasticks]]'', opens in New York City's [[Greenwich Village]], eventually becoming the longest-running [[musical theatre|musical]] of all time.
*  1960   &ndash; The [[Anne Frank House]] museum opens in [[Amsterdam]], Netherlands.
*[[1963]] &ndash; The police force in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] switches tactics and [[Birmingham campaign#Fire hoses and police dogs|responds with violent force]] to stop the "[[Birmingham campaign]]" protesters.  Images of the violent suppression are transmitted worldwide, bringing new-found attention to the [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1955–1968)|African-American Civil Rights Movement]].
*[[1973]] &ndash; The 108-story [[Sears Tower]] in Chicago is topped out at 1,451 feet as the [[world's tallest building]].
*[[1978]] &ndash; The first unsolicited bulk commercial [[e-mail]] (which would later become known as "[[spam (electronic)|spam]]") is sent by a [[Digital Equipment Corporation]] marketing representative to every [[ARPANET]] address on the west coast of the United States. 
*[[1979]] &ndash; After the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|general election]],  [[Margaret Thatcher]] forms her first  government as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
*[[1986]] &ndash; Twenty-one people are killed and forty-one are injured after a bomb explodes in an airliner (Flight UL512) at [[Colombo]] airport in [[Sri Lanka]].
*[[1987]] &ndash; A crash by [[Bobby Allison]] at the [[Talladega Superspeedway]], [[Alabama]] fencing at the start-finish line would lead [[NASCAR]] to develop the [[restrictor plate]] for the following season both at [[Daytona International Speedway]] and Talladega.
*[[1999]] &ndash; The southwestern portion of [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] is devastated by an [[1999 Bridge Creek – Moore tornado|F5 tornado]], killing forty-five people, injuring 665, and causing $1 billion in damage.  The tornado is one of 66 from the [[1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak]]. This tornado also produces the highest wind speed ever recorded, measured at 301 +/- 20&nbsp;mph (484 +/- 32&nbsp;km/h).
*[[2000]] &ndash; The sport of [[geocaching]] begins, with the first cache placed and the coordinates from a [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] posted on [[Usenet]].
*[[2001]] &ndash; The United States loses its seat on the [[U.N. Human Rights Commission]] for the first time since the commission was formed in [[1947]].
*[[2002]] &ndash; A military [[MiG-21]] aircraft crashes into the Bank of [[Rajasthan]] in India, killing eight.
*[[2003]] &ndash; [[New Hampshire]]'s famous [[Old Man of the Mountain]] collapses.
